name: Mystic Spiral
comment info:
It all points to awesome to me…

    Isn’t it awesome that in much of this world we have:
    - Birth control that gives women the ability to choose when and how many children to have 
    - Much reduced childhood mortality that means fewer children are necessary to ensure some will survive to become adults 
    - Greater educational opportunities and social freedoms for women, who may now choose their life’s path, rather than have it forced upon them 
    - population growth that is leveling out… I have little doubt we would eventually kill ourselves off if we grew unchecked. 
    
    The only downside? We will need to figure our way out of the economic ponzi scheme the modern markets have set up, that relies on ever increasing and expanding consumerism to not collapse.

name: geniusinwaiting
comment info:
Obviously, this is not news. There were reports and coverage on this topic over 20 years ago. 
    
    A UN report published in 2012 highlighted “…A significant factor, is that many people cannot have the number of children they want due to financial hardship, lack of quality healthcare, and societal barriers, rather than a lack of desire for children.”
    
    Birth rates have declined worldwide due to:
    
    1. women's improved education and access to jobs
    2. lower child mortality (fewer babies needed for family survival)
    3. rising costs of raising children
    4. better access to contraception
    5. increased urbanization (less farm labor needed)
    6. delayed marriage
    7. changing cultural values prioritizing careers and personal fulfillment over large families
    8. societal & future concerns with anxiety about climate change, economic instability, and political issues
    
    Sorry, no conspiracies, no nefariousness. So, what are we going to do to make it less expensive for folks to have and raise children?

name: Caitlin Waddick
comment info:
The decrease in the birth rate is due to human exposure to synthetic chemicals. 
    
    Sperm count is declining at an accelerated place globally. 
    
    Known and suspected endocrine disrupting chemicals are widespread due to our use of cosmetics and personal care products, pesticides, herbicides, fungicides, industrial chemicals, and metals (lead, cadmium, mercury, and arsenic are in paint and water pipelines, cigarette smoking, industrial emissions, fertilizers; coal burning; herbicides, fossil fuels). Biomonitoring studies continue to report routine human exposures to hundreds or thousands of chemicals. 
    
    The health outcomes in men, for example, are prostate cancer, testicular cancer, male infertility and sub fertility (sperm decline), hypogonadism (low testosterone), sexual dysfunctions, and intergenerational effects. 
    
    One in every 8 women will develop breast cancer during their lifetime, and it has to do with endocrine disrupting chemicals (EDCs). Science shows us how pesticide exposure impacts cancer aggressiveness and tumor immunopathology mechanisms.  
    
    Overall, human fertility is reduced.

name: Amos Grunebaum, MD
comment info: The dominant impression is that fertility rates have declined sharply and consistently across nearly all regions since the 1960s, converging toward or below replacement level. The United States, once well above two children per woman, has steadily fallen to European levels, while even historically high-fertility regions such as Mexico and much of Africa show long-term downward trajectories. Israel is a clear outlier, maintaining a notably higher and more stable fertility rate compared with other high-income countries.

name: geniusinwaiting
comment info:
Obviously, this is not news. There were reports and coverage on this topic over 20 years ago. 
    
    A UN report published in 2012 highlighted “…A significant factor, is that many people cannot have the number of children they want due to financial hardship, lack of quality healthcare, and societal barriers, rather than a lack of desire for children.”
    
    Birth rates have declined worldwide due to:
    
    1. women's improved education and access to jobs
    2. lower child mortality (fewer babies needed for family survival)
    3. rising costs of raising children
    4. better access to contraception
    5. increased urbanization (less farm labor needed)
    6. delayed marriage
    7. changing cultural values prioritizing careers and personal fulfillment over large families
    8. societal & future concerns with anxiety about climate change, economic instability, and political issues
    
    Sorry, no conspiracies, no nefariousness. So, what are we going to do to make it less expensive for folks to have and raise children?

name: Caitlin Waddick
comment info:
The decrease in the birth rate is due to human exposure to synthetic chemicals. 
    
    Sperm count is declining at an accelerated place globally. 
    
    Known and suspected endocrine disrupting chemicals are widespread due to our use of cosmetics and personal care products, pesticides, herbicides, fungicides, industrial chemicals, and metals (lead, cadmium, mercury, and arsenic are in paint and water pipelines, cigarette smoking, industrial emissions, fertilizers; coal burning; herbicides, fossil fuels). Biomonitoring studies continue to report routine human exposures to hundreds or thousands of chemicals. 
    
    The health outcomes in men, for example, are prostate cancer, testicular cancer, male infertility and sub fertility (sperm decline), hypogonadism (low testosterone), sexual dysfunctions, and intergenerational effects. 
    
    One in every 8 women will develop breast cancer during their lifetime, and it has to do with endocrine disrupting chemicals (EDCs). Science shows us how pesticide exposure impacts cancer aggressiveness and tumor immunopathology mechanisms.  
    
    Overall, human fertility is reduced.

name: Amos Grunebaum, MD
comment info: The dominant impression is that fertility rates have declined sharply and consistently across nearly all regions since the 1960s, converging toward or below replacement level. The United States, once well above two children per woman, has steadily fallen to European levels, while even historically high-fertility regions such as Mexico and much of Africa show long-term downward trajectories. Israel is a clear outlier, maintaining a notably higher and more stable fertility rate compared with other high-income countries.

name: Phillip Evans
comment info: The graph shows that birthrates have decreased globally over the last 65 years, with most countries now below two children per woman, which is the replacement rate needed to maintain a stable population. Trends noticed include a steady decline in the United States and a more dramatic drop in Mexico, and regions like the Middle East and North Africa historically had higher birthrates than other regions. Questions raised include why birthrates vary by region and gender, what factors influence birth rates, and why some see the decline as positive while others view it as negative.

name: Alan
comment info:
The current world economy is utterly dependent on growth or it stagnates. 
    
    All countries face a decline in birth rates, but for different reasons. In the developing world food security and improved healthcare means people don’t need to have a lot of children to offset the high mortality rate amongst the under five’s. In the first world however, increased costs and the requirement for two incomes means children are often deferred or denied. 
    
    The real question is why people are having to work harder for less?
    
    Examining the current US economy gives some huge clues.

name: Howard
comment info:
1. I noticed that fertility rates have been steadily declining across almost all regions of the world since 1960. Countries like the U.S., France, Canada, and Norway all dropped from above 3 children per woman to around or below 2. Some regions, especially Central & Western Africa, still have higher fertility rates, but even those show a downward trend.
    2. I wonder why fertility rates dropped so dramatically across so many places. Is it due to economic changes, cultural shifts, women’s education, urbanization, cost of living, or access to contraception?
    3. In many communities today—including mine—people are having fewer children because of financial pressure, busy work lifestyles, and a desire for career stability. Many young adults feel that raising kids is expensive and challenging.
    4. From Boom to Decline: Fertility Rates Fall Worldwide

    b) as national GDP increases, people don’t have to count on having their sole support in old age being their children.

name: Deb
comment info:
These graphs remind me of the old saying my college history professor had.... statistics don't lie, statisticians do. 
    
    Even though birth rates globally are going down, the world population is rising.  The reason - lower infant mortality rates.  Particularly in the more advanced countries, for the last 2-3 generations, the child mortality rate has been very low.  The first generation or 2 still had multiple children out of habit, but since all of them lived, it got expensive.   The next generations had fewer children.  The children were also no longer needed as farm laborers, so the need to have 10 kids to help run the house and farm (or Alternatively go work in a factory at a young age to support the family) is no longer necessary.  
    
    This is not something to be surprised or scared of.  It is a good thing.  Less children dying and they have better childhoods in most cases.  The real headline here should be that better childhood outcomes lead to the need for less children.

replies.name: C
replies.comment info: @Deb not sure if one’s history professor is the best source for learning about statistics, but regardless, you’re comparing apples and oranges here. The graph is about declining birth rates. It doesn’t make any claims about the overall world population.

replies.name: J
replies.comment info:
@Deb
    Population levels aren’t dropping because there is a lag in population levels and birthrates.  The population of a country reflects historic birthrates, not current ones because people generally live decades.  Population levels in many countries will drop and will continue to drop for years and years - it is a mathematical inevitability.  Ultimately most economically advanced countries will see their healthcare and pension systems collapse and their economies shrink.

name: Juliette AOSE
comment info: I notice that from 1960 to 2020, global birth rates have all declined. With minor fluctuations, there is an overall trend of women having fewer children. I observe that countries that are generally less affluent and have less infrastructure tend to have higher birth rates. Most women now opt to have only 1-2 children, with Central and Western Africa and Eastern and Southern Asia being exceptions, still having around 4-5 children. I wonder if this is directly influenced by the widespread women's rights and equality movements. Women today have more autonomy and face less social pressure to have children. These movements have also enabled women to pursue careers first and families later, which likely leads to fewer children. I also wonder if increased access to education plays a role. Girls are no longer dropping out of school to become wives and mothers; instead, they learn about sex education and contraceptives. The rise in autonomy means women can choose when to have children and have more control over their lives. I also consider whether the cost of living impacts this trend, making it less realistic to have many children and support a large family, even on two incomes. This affects me and my community because lower birth rates could lead to an underpopulation issue. From excess housing to economic consequences, a significant decrease in population size could cause many negative effects.

name: Linh Vu
comment info:
I notice that, from 1960 to 2020, all examined countries and regions underwent declines in the average number of children born per mother. Mexico showed the most significant drop (from about 6.8 in 1960 to about 1.8 in 2020), with the steepest decline recorded from around 1972 to 1986. The same pattern could be seen in the Middle East and North Africa, with the steepest decline taking place a decade later. In stark contrast, the Central & Western Africa and Eastern & Southern Africa regions experienced a relatively mild decrease, from 6.5 to slightly below 5 and from 6.8 to 4.2, respectively, retaining their leading positions throughout the period. Meanwhile, figures from the US, Canada, and several EU countries remained at the bottom, hovering around 1.5-2 children per mother in 2020.
    
    An outstanding figure to me is the East Asia & Pacific, which showed a dramatic rise around 1962 before gradually declining in the following decade. I wonder what socio-economic factors played a role in such noticeable changes in this region. 
    
    Other than that, the US and Canada showed a similar trajectory throughout the period. I wonder what similar factors regarding policies, living conditions, and perceptions in these 2 countries might lead to such similarities.

name: Maria
comment info:
Based on the graph, the average number of births per woman, recorded from 1960 to today, generally decreases, although there are some differences between cultures.
    African women still have higher birth rates than in any other continent, especially in the central and southern regions, where the rate dropped from about 6.5 to 4.5 on average.
    The most significant drops can be seen in Mexico (from 6.8 to 1.8), Latin America & the Caribbean (from 6 to 2), and East Asia & the South Pacific (from 4 to 2).
    Europe, the U.S., and Canada show only a slight decrease, mostly after 1970, from about 2 children per woman to around 1.5.
    
    I wonder why birth rates remain high in some regions that face serious political and economic challenges. Might it be connected to cultural traditions, limited access to education and healthcare, or lack of social support for women?
    Migration caused by these conditions changes the population structure and cultural diversity of many countries, including the UK.
    
    Headline: “How the World Is Changing Through Falling Birth Rates”

name: Matthew
comment info: As we know, this make old people more numerous than the younger ones and creates a problem of supporting the older people with a smaller number of younger people that also need to support themselves. This situation leaves young people critically exposed as they are not only expected to preform this labour and "keep the society running", it also leaves them without much influence over it and its politics, as they are lesser in numbers to old people, and therefore any democratic change favouring young people is near impossible, as old people have a majority over them. This leaves young people, like myself, asking, how can we support our increasingly aging population when there is so few of us and so many of them? I believe the answer is immigration, because, if done properly, immigration helps rebalance the demographical structure and fills essential jobs that are needed. Of course this opens other questions of integration, national integrity and identity and global influence, including problems for poorer countries, such as brain drain. However, the immigrant usually do continue contributing to their home country and this push might be a strong current to push the country towards development. Here in Switzerland, immigrants quickly integrate into society due to integration programs and preform all kinds of jobs that the native Swiss population might not have the quantity to do. This leaves Switzerland largely demographically stable, despite low birth rate.

name: Sophia
comment info: What I noticed in the graph is that in 1960, Mexico used to have almost 7 children on average, and then in 2020 it went down to almost 3. I also noticed that in 1960, Canada had almost 4 children on average, and then it went down to 2. Lastly, the overall average of the children born to a woman in those regions and countries dropped down significantly. What do you wonder? I wonder why some of the birth rates went down as the years passed, it is too much money to raise them? How come earlier in the years, like 1960, half of the regions had almost higher than 4 children born? What made it so common to have more babies in the early years? This relates to my community because it shows that we no longer want to have that many kids anymore. China's a great example of this, because they implied a rule that said you could only have one child. The policy wasn’t too great though, because there was gender imbalance and a lot of old people, with less young people to help them. The government tried to fix it by increasing the policy rate to 3, and paying you for your children, but China’s population is still growing too slow. How does this relate to your community? This is important because it shows that this same problem with less birthrates could happen to other regions and countries later in the future. Catchy headline- Average number of children born: Are our birthrates gradually decreasing as the years pass? How will this affect our population rate and the environment?
